[Michael Abbink](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230108/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Michael%20Abbink) with [Paul van der Laan](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230108/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Paul%20van%20der%20Laan)

The initial work on FF Kievit occurred in 1995 as part of a school project and was finished several years later for a corporate client of Method Inc., a design firm in San Francisco. The openness of the characters and their proportions makes it an ideal typeface for use in small print. The clarity of classic sans serif faces ( [Frutiger](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230108/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Frutiger) and [Univers](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230108/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Univers)) and the humanistic characteristics of old styles ( [Garamond](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230108/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Garamond) and [Granjon](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414230108/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Granjon)) were the inspiration for this contemporary design that is equally at home in a headline or a body of text. The FF Kievit family includes six weights, true italics, old style figures and small caps -- everything necessary for even the most demanding typography.
